comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Apparently built 1818 as a fancy shed to store explosives in while the Donaghadee harbour was being built.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
If I'm right about the direction, I think the shed is actually marked on the 6"
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] not necessarily the bomb shed marked - just a shed shed.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: An 1837 letter to the Belfast News-lette r from J.T. of Donaghadee claims that it was originally a burial chamber. He quotes someone else saying "it is hollow and consists of a number of rooms passing each other at right angles, used by the Danes as an armoury". Also "A ridge of earth, known as the Giant's Grave, stretches north-east by the base of the mound, which according to tradition, indicates the burial-place of these worthies" In 1831 Lt Tucker of the Royal Sappers and Miners had dug into it and found an 18"x9" sepulchral urn.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Interesting. So is it a barrow or was it just built with a cellar for the tower of a motte and bailey?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The Leeds Mercury (Leeds, England), Thursday, May 14, 1891
Alleged Dynamite Outrage In Ireland At Newtonards, county Down, correspondent telegraphs - The Moat magazine at Donaghadee in that county, has been blown up by dynamite. A stranger with a pronounced American accent has been seen in the vicinity, but no arrests have been made. A later telegram from Belfast says that the explosion at Donaghadee is a very trifling affair. It took place on Tuesday, and the damage is insignificant.
In other words, nothing much happened.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I imagine the qualities of the site which encouraged the Normans to build there would also have appealed to other peoples over preceding millennia, whether for defence or as a prominent place to bury your heroic forebears.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here's a recreation of this view: www.donaghadeehistoricalsociety.org.uk/#/the-moat/4548244275

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
Apparently there's bugger all there: 

MOAT STREET, TOWNPARKS, DONAGHADEE
Ongoing
J13798708
AE/09/66 and AE/09/176
Work is ongoing at this site. Nothing of archaeological significance has so far been uncovered.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: "The little stream that first gave life to the settlement that became Donaghadee still flows into the sea and, overlooking the North Channel, stands the Norman motte - one of the largest in Northern Ireland and known as “The Moat”. Only the great 150-foot mound is Norman, the “castle” at its summit is believed to have been built in 1819 as an impressive store for the gunpowder used in the construction work of the new harbour – although Harry mentioned that there was no documentary record of this. All traces of its ancient keep, which was probably of wood, would have been swept away when this structure was built. Climbing the motte is always worth the trouble. It is said that from the summit on a clear day one can see five kingdoms." uas.society.qub.ac.uk/newsletter/Dec%202007.pdf

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: This Streetview is the closest to the photo above - you just get a glimpse of it between the houses on East St. It looks like the the surrounding wall has been modified in the interim period with one of the towers no missing.

Time to stop the Monty Python angle before it gets out of control.
 Sorry I can't resist.
Apart from a system of government, a language , an infusion of new blood, all the Fitzs (except Fitzpatrick) Burkes, Joyces etc, a grievence that sustained generations for 800 years what indeed did the Normans do for us?

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: There is no great mystery to "Motte & Bailey" castes since they were all documented extensively. You can find the locations for them in Northern Ireland here - www.doeni.gov.uk/niea/built-home/information/normans_in_i... along with illustrations.
